morning.text: The streams of living water which flow from Jerusalem are not dried up by the parching heats of sultry midsummer any more than they were frozen by the cold winds of blustering winter. Rejoice, O my soul, that thou art spared to testify of the faithfulness of the Lord. The seasons change and thou changest, but thy Lord abides evermore the same, and the streams of His love are as deep, as broad and as full as ever. The heats of business cares and scorching trials make me need the cooling influences of the river of His grace; I may go at once and drink to the full from the inexhaustible fountain, for in summer and in winter it pours forth its flood. The upper springs are never scanty, and blessed be the name of the Lord, the nether springs cannot fail either. Elijah found Cherith dry up, but Jehovah was still the same God of providence. Job said his brethren were like deceitful brooks, but he found his God an overflowing river of consolation. The Nile is the great confidence of Egypt, but its floods are variable; our Lord is evermore the same. By turning the course of the Euphrates, Cyrus took the city of Babylon, but no power, human or infernal, can divert the current of divine grace. The tracks of ancient rivers have been found all dry and desolate, but the streams which take their rise on the mountains of divine sovereignty and infinite love shall ever be full to the brim. Generations melt away, but the course of grace is unaltered. The river of God may sing with greater truth than the brook in the poem—"Men may come, and men may go, But I go on for ever." How happy art thou, my soul, to be led beside such still waters! Never wander to other streams, lest thou hear the Lord's rebuke, "What hast thou to do in the way of Egypt to drink of the muddy river?"

evening.text: My soul, now that the cool of the day has come, retire awhile and hearken to the voice of thy God. He is always ready to speak with thee when thou art prepared to hear. If there be any slowness to commune it is not on His part, but altogether on thine own, for He stands at the door and knocks, and if His people will but open He rejoices to enter. But in what state is my heart, which is my Lord’s garden? May I venture to hope that it is well trimmed and watered, and is bringing forth fruit fit for Him? If not, He will have much to reprove, but still I pray Him to come unto me, for nothing can so certainly bring my heart into a right condition as the presence of the Sun of Righteousness, who brings healing in His wings. Come, therefore, O Lord, my God, my soul invites Thee earnestly, and waits for Thee eagerly. Come to me, O Jesus, my well-beloved, and plant fresh flowers in my garden, such as I see blooming in such perfection in Thy matchless character! Come, O my Father, who art the Husbandman, and deal with me in Thy tenderness and prudence! Come, O Holy Spirit, and bedew my whole nature, as the herbs are now moistened with the evening dews. O that God would speak to me. Speak, Lord, for Thy servant heareth! O that He would walk with me; I am ready to give up my whole heart and mind to Him, and every other thought is hushed. I am only asking what He delights to give. I am sure that He will condescend to have fellowship with me, for He has given me His Holy Spirit to abide with me for ever. Sweet is the cool twilight, when every star seems like the eye of heaven, and the cool wind is as the breath of celestial love. My Father, my elder Brother, my sweet Comforter, speak now in lovingkindness, for Thou hast opened mine ear and I am not rebellious.

morning.text: And I will walk at liberty: for I seek thy precepts. The liberty here meant is liberty from sin, liberty to holiness. It is the liberty of love, not of licentiousness. Let us not think that because we are free we may therefore do what we like. The Apostle Paul tells us that we are not our own, we are bought with a price. Our liberty is to walk in the commandments of God. When the Son makes us free, we are free indeed. Let us not abuse our freedom, but use it to glorify God. Let us walk at liberty, because we seek His precepts. Let us not be entangled again with the yoke of bondage. Let us stand fast in the liberty wherewith Christ hath made us free.

evening.text: Ye are the salt of the earth. What a privilege! What a responsibility! Salt is a preservative. It keeps things from corruption. So the Christian is to keep the world from moral decay. Salt is also a seasoning. It gives flavor. So the Christian is to give a savor of grace to society. But salt must be pure. It must not lose its savor. If it does, it is good for nothing. Let us be careful to maintain our spiritual vitality. Let us not be conformed to this world. Let us be transformed by the renewing of our minds. Let us be the salt of the earth indeed.

morning.text: There is therefore now no condemnation to them which are in Christ Jesus. This is a glorious truth. The believer is free from condemnation. The law cannot condemn him. Sin cannot condemn him. Satan cannot condemn him. Christ has borne the condemnation. He has satisfied justice. He has made peace by the blood of His cross. Let us rejoice in this freedom. Let us walk in the Spirit. Let us not fulfill the lusts of the flesh. Let us live as those who are not condemned, but justified, sanctified, and glorified.

evening.text: Yea, though I walk through the valley of the shadow of death, I will fear no evil. This is the confidence of the believer. Death is but a shadow. It cannot harm him. Christ has conquered death. He has taken away its sting. He has given us victory. Let us not fear death. Let us look beyond it to the glory that shall be revealed. Let us trust in the Good Shepherd who leads us through the valley. He is with us. His rod and His staff comfort us. Let us rest in His love and care.

morning.text: Stand fast therefore in the liberty wherewith Christ hath made us free. This is a call to perseverance. Let us not be moved from our hope. Let us not be entangled again with the yoke of bondage. Christ has set us free. Let us walk in that freedom. Let us not be subject to legalism. Let us not seek justification by works. Let us live by faith. Let us rejoice in the grace of God. Let us stand fast in the liberty of the gospel.

evening.text: Thou wilt keep him in perfect peace, whose mind is stayed on thee. This is the secret of peace. It is found in trust. It is found in steadfastness. Let us fix our minds on God. Let us meditate on His Word. Let us trust in His promises. Let us rest in His love. Let us not be anxious. Let us not be troubled. Let us cast our cares on Him. He cares for us. He will keep us in perfect peace.

morning.text: Peace I leave with you, my peace I give unto you. This is the legacy of Christ. He gives us peace. Not as the world gives. His peace is deep. It is abiding. It is divine. Let us receive it. Let us cherish it. Let us not let our hearts be troubled. Let us not be afraid. Let us trust in Him. He is our peace. He has reconciled us to God. He has made peace by the blood of His cross.

evening.text: I will both lay me down in peace, and sleep: for thou, Lord, only makest me dwell in safety. This is the rest of faith. The believer can sleep in peace. He is safe in the arms of God. Let us not fear the night. Let us not be troubled by darkness. Let us trust in the Lord. He watches over us. He gives His beloved sleep. Let us rest in Him. Let us dwell in safety.
